better yet, just paste an MIT style disclaimer in front of the code and be set.

_8jean: anyhow, if you can rip the XML parse out of closure and morph it into a library for general purpose use, i'd be more than happy. we could then host it on this new common-lisp.net site.
gilberth: what license would it be under? ISTR kire had thoughts of doing this but the license for closure is GPL not LGPL
I'll have a look at it anyway. The alternative would probably be porting CL-XML to mlisp. No idea whether that would be easy or futile.
chandler: The Closure policy is [was] keep the "app" GPL while allowing libraries getting LGPL on demand. (e.g. the SGML stuff is LGPL). Today I lean more towards something "free" like BSD style.
chandler: btw, cl-irc's tracking of users joined in a channel made it very easy to properly log non-channled events like quit and nick. very nice.
Also I'd like rip the useful stuff out of Closure and morph it into libraries. unfortunately i forsee very, very little free time for 2004.

Fufie: We need a real library with DOM, not just a read-once-then-throw-away parser. If anything, we could do FFI to libxml2, which we are using anyway. But I don't really feel like basing DOM on FFI.

In doing logical pathname translation, the matching rules are the same as pathname-match-p, which are 'implementation defined'. In other words, you can't count on a damned thing, even with the supposed portable filename mechanism.
cliini: we've found out what the pathname chapter means. It means very little.
pfdietz: besides being a chronic headache for all CL implementors?
Well, you can pretty much count on being able to re-read a file from the same LPN you've written it to, no?
does sbcl have a sane lpn implementation?
"before 2004, the matching algorithm is as follows: ...; from the 1st January 2004 henceforth, however..."
piso: not quite. There is some hairiness in version matching, I think
I'd been hoping for a set of tests to act as a safety harness before I investigated, though :-/
I'm thinking (grasping at straws) that it might be plausible to codify some sort of current practice, if there is any that's worth codifying...
(this in addition to the point that it is impossible to have a sane CL pathname implementation when your native filesystem is Unix)
krystof: Yeah, I was kind of assuming the same implementation throughout.
Krystof: That is something that needs to be fixed.
I've been thinking about looking at using ISO9660 for my data, without the unix translation layer.
rydis: not mandated by the standard, I believe :-)
Krystof: what's the problem with pathnames and unix?
Yeah, it's not safe from perverted reading. :) (Queue the story about DEFVAR and the isolated hacker implementing a really convoluted method to follow the spec from CLtL1.)
pfdietz: File types, primarily, I'd imagine.
Ah. What do you do if the filename has more than one dot in it.
Or has one in an odd position, I guess.
Is that a completely intractable problem?
Also, what's the name and type of .emacs?
the name is ".emacs". there is no type
the type follows the dot, unless there's nothing preceding the dot
what about the name and type of #foo.c# ?
CMUCL used to croak horribly on my #.emacs# files. :)
make: don't know how to make progress. Stop
except now there's no portable interface to mac- or BeOS-like metadata
Hell, as far as I can tell the implementor has license to do nearly anything he damned well pleases.
I'm not sure about device or version.
pathname code isn't portable, it's ported
kalh: because lispms and many other systems traditionally had it. if we're going to LCD ourselves, let's LCD away directories
kalh: Because it's a non-sucky solution. CL should accomodate those. :)
pfdietz: at least there's a portable list of names to call to lay hands on that undefined behaviour :)
in fact files are really kept separate with type on Palm :-)
On systems with no directories, the directory can just be NIL.
Systems with no (recursive?) directories are handled in the LPN chapter of CLtL2.
chandler: what is the metadata problem?
pfdietz: the problem is that I think there is no place for anything in :type in a unix filesystem
Maybe an interface to magic(5) would be somehow appropriate. ;)
I think e.g. the file strcmp.3.gz is best represented as :name "strcmp.3.gz" :type nil :version :whatever
but I can't do that, because of compile-file-pathname
in particular, I would like to represent "foo.lisp" as :name "foo.lisp" :type nil
but thanks to ANSI running out of patience, I can't
So the files that C-F-P works on need to have the right :type ("lsp", "lisp", "l", "cl", say), as does its output ("fasl" or whatever), but anything else can just use :name.
The pathname constructor is allowed to 'canonicalize' pathnames at any point.
I thought we weren't certain of that
also, compile-file-pathname is required to work on arbitrary pathnames, is it not?
(I actually wouldn't have any objection to changing the output file to be "foo.lisp.fasl", but it's still hideously ugly as an implementation requirement)
Is it possible to just use type for .lisp and .fasl files?
I.e. support C-F-P and nothing else.
or at least, you'd get violently nonintuitive behaviour (!surprise!)
yes, but I think I'd expect that

It'd be nice if there was a "standard" implementation of LPN:s (like the one Mark Kantrowitz wrote) like there is for LOOP (ok, not everyone uses it, but most implementations at least provide it, or extend it).
LOOP at least has a mostly-coherent standard
no such thing currently exists for "L"PNs
what's wrong with the current c-f-p behaviour?
it requires a meaningful :type field in pathnames
when various filesystems, notably Unix ones, have no such meaning
(Note too that Windows, which is popular in some quarters, has many of the same limitations as Unix in this regard.)
It seems to me is what you need is a well-defined namestring parsing algorithm for unix.
I think sbcl's current usage of :type is just fine. is it problematic in some ways?
Ignore the :type unless you really need it internally in CL.
Which means lisp source, lisp compiled files, and not anything (?) else.
pfdietz: now, if you were to tell me that I can canonicalize the result of compile-file-pathname at any time, then maybe I hit nirvana
as I said, I think sbcl's current usage is fine, i.e. "" for ".emacs" and ".el " for ".emacs.el" looks ok to me
Krystof: sbcl seems to do sensible things for all of the examples quoted (agreeing with azu here)
I don't believe that they're sensible
On the page for MAKE-PATHNAME: "Whenever a pathname is constructed the components may be canonicalized if appropriate."
is this usage problematic in some ways or is it just that you don't like it?
so. Does Compile-file-pathname involve constructing a pathname?
azu: it's problematic in that these edge cases are nonintuitive
I think I've just proved my point
Do people really count on ..x having a well-defined type?
In the same way foo.lisp has a type?
they can't possibly. But I'd like them to be clearly not misled
what's the type of "/etc/sbclrc"? Why is it not "lisp"?
Which would mean the :type field should not be filled in.
Can the implementation not make (and document) a few rules, about how it construes the type?
piso: the implementation has broad leeway here.
And the next good step would be for >1 implementation to follow the same rule(s).
Krystof: I think the rule should be that :type gets used if the underlying filesystem has a notion of type, or if CL requires it. Otherwise, just use :name.
I think if I'm allowed to canonicalize :name "foo.lisp" :type "fasl" to :name "foo.lisp.fasl", I might give it a try and see how many complaints I get
pfdietz, that sounds to me as logical as the current rules are, but less useful
ACL treats the final . as preceeding the type, unless it's the first character in the namestring.
Which seems to me a good rule.
If there is no ., :type is NIL.
I don't think this _is_ reasonable on a unix filesystem
If there is only a leading ., :type is also NIL.
or indeed any filesystem without a semantic type component
I may just rip out the pathname tests. They don't leave me feeling clean.
leave them in but don't load them by default
krystof: I thought SBCL had versions, as well. Hmm.
rydis: I sincerely hope not. CMUCL does, and it's almost totally broken
pfdietz: you need an ansi-tests/nonstandard directory ;)
krystof: #p"foo.bar.1" prints as #p"foo.bar", and has a version field of 1.
OK, that's less broken that cmucl's support
I like CMUCL:s understanding ~n~-stuff, but I guess most people don't use that kind of versioning. :)
rydis: where n is an integer? No. And also, try translating logical pathnames to it
krystof: You probably can't in conforming, portable userspace, no. Doing it in the implementation seems quite possible.
(But I've only looked at it slightly, before CMUCL got that support.)
rydis: no, I mean something like (("FOO:**;*.*.*" "/tmp/**/*.*.*")) as (logical-pathname-translations "FOO")
What does it do on foo.bar.newest ?
sbcl treats newest as the type
That probably depends on in what context, for CMUCL, IIRC.
CMUCL recent parses "foo.lsp.1" as having type "1".
pfdietz: Not when it's a logical pathname, does it?
Oh, no, I was parsing a pathname namestring.
Inrterestingly, ACL does not translate the name and type fields to uppercase when parsing logical pathnames.
Yeah, for unix namestrings it's foo.bar.~n~. In logical pathnames, I think it works with .newest and .1, as (my, a few months old, reading of) the standard mandates.
ACL's behavior directly violates 19.3.1.1.7, but good for them.
there is no semantic :type in Unix; hence, it shouldn't have one painfully bolted on in CL.
This seems moderately obvious to me, but then I have spent the last year beating my head against the standard...

OTOH, newish versions of for instance linux filesystems have versioning (and other metadata) support, though not ordinarily visible to the user. (I think most other "modern" unix filesystems have something similar, but haven't looked at it closely. I expect it to be wildly different between versions.)

dan-b: Dunno. I haven't looked at it closely enough to know. It'd be interesting to have, for instance, a CVS device that uses CVS for versions on files, and possibly likewise for RCS, Arch, Subversion, what have you.
(Or maybe not device; some sort of host might be better. Dunno.)
dan-b: Right. Didn't think about that. That'd go in something like the device part, if you have a CVS host-family, perhaps?
dan-b: re your latest diary entry; what are the sizes of the static spaces / read-only spaces in cmucl and your sbcls?
in particular, I suspect sbcl is holding on to lots of garbage
But I don't really understand CVS (or versioning), so don't mind me.
that would account for the difference between 30 and 15 seconds

or maybe one of those 19.1.6.5.1.2.17 sections

that is in your application frame layout?
is that how you create gadgets?

(:panes (display application)) quite frankly I don't understand what this means, just copied it from examples
where are you calling make-pane from, then?
creating the pane doesn't magically insert it into the window
you can do that using sheet-adopt-child, but you probably want to create the button inside define-application-frame
(also, if you are using make-pane outside of define-application-frame, remember to use with-look-and-feel-realization)
what should be the argument to make-pane's :client initarg? *app-frame* itself, or (get-frame-pane *app-frame* 'pane)? or what else?
the latter, but you normally don't have to do that..
you probably want something like (:panes (mybutton (make-pane ...))) inside define-application-frame, and then change the :layouts section to include 'mybutton' somewhere

most probably, yes. I suppose it depends whether you think of handling or trapping errors
is there the same functionality as something else than a condition?
matju: another nitpick: there's no such thing as a function name. CL has symbols for naming things
happy new year rtoy (and all). minor changes are good, yes
jdz: that's pretty much of a nitpick. In some languages i use, a name is assumed to be a symbol.
jdz: "symbol" is the data type, "name" is the use you make of it
(undefined-function is a subclass of cell-error, so, that might be what you're looking for.)
matju: did you get the answer you wanted?

no, i don't want a condition, i want a symbol for which i can define a function that will be called whenever a symbol has no function bound to it; and that function would default to being defined as just signalling the undefined-function condition
further examples of what i want: ObjC's "forwardInvocation:" and Perl's "AUTOLOAD"
Oh. There are a few such generic functions in CLOS, but not in CL in general, as far as I recall.
well, if CLOS defines it, it must be because it can be defined in CL itself, isn't it?
matju: you can do it by having your hanler for undefined-function condition which might refuse to handle the condition
matju: but anyway you want to look at the undefined-function condition, and handler-bind
matju: The way to do it in CL is to handle undefined-function or cell-error, I'd think.

why do people fret so much about GC, don't they realize that malloc and free cost CPU time too?

no, I'm talking about sun's jvm
mark-and-sweep for some set of older generations

yeah, jni has lots of crap because you need to explicitly allow the jvm to convert to c datatypes
it's really only glaring when dealing with arrays of primitives

it's a very complex GC and from my experience, it's not very fast
